pr_title: Adding Enum of MSALCPP in SdkType

timeline.message:
Adding Enum of MSALCPP in SdkType

Adding Enum of MSALCPP in SdkType, to help defferentiate between MSAL and MSALCPP.

Another aspect is to remove teh dependency on Device.java, for teh purpose of using dynamic x-client-SKU and x-client-Ver Values, which are to be passed around from CommandParameter and BrokerRequest

timeline.bodyText: Move this to Authentication Constants

timeline.bodyText: Do we actually need to send this to the Broker? IIRC, MSAL / ADAL we don't need to send it based on the current design around adapters. Perhaps it is need for CPP?
timeline.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: Yes it is need for CPP.
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: It wasn't sent initially because Android.MSAL value was being hardcoded on the receiving end.
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: Can you share CPP model for sending/unpacking broker request? Are they not using (custom) adapters?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText:
@shahzaibj  CPP will need to set SdkType as MSALCPP here and version too. Tanmay should make the changes there after this.
broker request will send this to broker (it will be MSAL or MSALCPP based on the library)
replies.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText:
@kreedula I'm looking for the code where Broker will unpack the BrokerRequest that was sent to it via MSALCPP.
In broker, we currently have the IBrokerRequestAdapter, and we have implementations of it for ADAL/MSAL, but I don't see one for MSALCPP. Which adapter does MSALCPP use?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: it's the same format , i.e. common sends the request to broker . MSAL CPP just uses BrokerMSALController" to call acquireTokenoracquireTokenSilent`
replies.author: kreedula

timeline.bodyText: What's being attached to DiagnosticContext here? As far as I can see nothing.....and I think this method could easily stay inside Device.java. Is there a specific reason for moving it here?
timeline.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: There could be some more code optimizations done, and having all the constants in a single place would help. It would be then easier to have these constants accessible from a single place. Hence setting it up for the later use. @kreedula anything I missed?
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: Well I would like to keep all of it in Device.java and use it in DiagonisticContext to put all the parameters inside this. And later , you get the map from DiagnosticContext.

timeline.bodyText: you can actually put this in the enum itself, since each of them is a class underneath.  Give the whole thing either an abstract method or a method returning whatever we're agreeing on for "I don't know what this is that's calling me" and then override it as appropriate for each of the values in your enumeration, and you'll be done, with no crazy branches.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: Same comment mentioned applies here as well, since we are hardcoding the values in every request, there isnt a way where we could encounter any funny values, and hence only the values used in the enum would be considered for getProductName.
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: This enumeration looks like it exists on the interface between broker and MSAL - is that correct?
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: This means that at some point this exists as a series of bytes in IPC.  You do not know what is going to land on the other side, since it can be newer or older than what you expect.  We're going to decouple this layer in the broker to allow for us to pivot the serialization mechanisms more smoothly, but this means that there will be cases where you will not be able to put the SDKType into a bucket with which you are familiar. What will you do in that case?
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText:
@AdamBJohnsonx In this case, this wont be a blocker since, for the mentioned cases :


new MSAL - old broker : the old broker wont have the sdktype and even if the new MSAL sends the new sdktype (msal.cpp) the broker will neglect it and use the hardcoded value of sdktype (msal)


old msal - new broker : since old msal wont be sending the sdktype, the new broker has a default value of selecting msal as sdktype.


old msal - old broker : working fine


new msal - new broker : working fine


I am going to be testing these e2e scenarios just to make sure, we see the flow we are expecting to see, I would post the results here.
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: Why is it OK if the old broker cannot accurately report the sdk type?
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: Since the old broker is already deployed and is in production(the current implementation) is using the common which uses the hardcoded value? I mean to say, this added new functionality wont break the functionality of the broker versions already in the market today not having this change.
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: Let's just make sure that having the divergence won't crash the broker in the event of an either-way-mismatch, and you're good to go after that.  We'll take on making this forwards-compatible for the next SDK addition later, and revisit any parameter that's similarly dangerous.
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

timeline.bodyText: could I make a plug here for adding an UNKNOWN value here.  But if we're going to fail things because they don't know the magic string, then we could at least log what the heck they sent us.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: The sdktype is hardcoded in the logic when creating the requests, so technically we should only encounter one of these values.
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: Sure.  Now.  But that might not be true forever.
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: For now, this is an enum so I don't expect it to be anything other than the values currently declared in the SdkType.java. @AdamBJohnsonx not clear to me how this could be an unknow value....are you anticipating something specific?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: Do we know why it wasn't being picked up? because you said earlier that when null was passed then the default was working as expected and setting it to MSAL -- so in what cases does it not work? and why?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: I meant that if the field is not sent over the wire, we have nothing to compare against null on the receiving end. The annotation as well wasn't a good addition, it was a part of an experimentation which I was trying out, and missed out on actually servicing it.
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: But if there is nothing, isn't there the initial value of null for all java objects? I mean the default should be kicking in whether you pass null to the builder or pass nothing
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: Is this coming through Parcelable?
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText:
The Builder.Default is broken according to Some, and seems like people are recommending against using it. This might explain the builder not picking up the value passed.
projectlombok/lombok#1347

replies.bodyText: @AdamBJohnsonx  I dont think its coming through parcelable.

timeline.message:
Updates for making sure the CI test case doesnt fail

The CI test case constructs a CommandParameter object with null values for every field. hence commandParameters.getSdkType().getProductName() was breaking the CI build.

timeline.bodyText: Are there any other cases where this could happen (besides the test)? and should we pick a better default value for such scenarios?
timeline.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: Realistically, we should accept any String that a client sends us and choose to sanitize it accordingly.  If that means accepting anything of a given pattern and converting everything else to UNKNOWN and pushing the transmitted value over telemetry as unknownClientSpecifier = , that's perfect.
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: No, there wouldn't be any such scenarios, since these values are coded when the requests are being spawned. These exist only in the test case. and with this implementation the test cases are also taken care of and are executed successfully.
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: There is also an additional null check for this field on the broker side, when rebuilding the CommandParameters from the BrokerRequest.
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: I've made a bug to remove type-sharing from this interface, since it's just a problem waiting to happen.
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: @AdamBJohnsonx yes I agree, since this field is not exposed to user input, hence it is safeguarded by that. And like you suggested there is a refactor task needed with certain fields involved in interaction over wire and once things settle down we can club in this change as well
replies.author: tanmaymanolkar1

replies.bodyText: @tanmaymanolkar1 - don't be so trusting. You could get anything over that interface and it shouldn't crash you.
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

replies.bodyText: @tanmaymanolkar1 I think you can create a constant for unknown and use that here....I don't personally like the empty string
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: Did we mean to do this or not? If not, then let's remove the comment.

+     * empty string otherwise(UNKNOWN).
      */

         if ((SdkType.ADAL == this) || (SdkType.MSAL == this)) {
